Synopsis 
 
Dans le chÃƒÂ¢teau des Chatterley, Constance coule des jours monotones, enfermÃƒÂ©e dans son mariage et son sens du devoir.
Au printemps, au coeur de la forÃƒÂªt de Wragby, elle fait la connaissance de Parkin, le garde-chasse du domaine. Le film est leur histoire.
Le rÃƒÂ©cit d&#039;une rencontre, d&#039;un difficile apprivoisement, d&#039;un lent ÃƒÂ©veil ÃƒÂ  la sensualitÃƒÂ© pour elle, d&#039;un long retour ÃƒÂ  la vie pour lui. Ou comment l&#039;amour ne fait qu&#039;un avec l&#039;expÃƒÂ©rience de la transformation.

A magnificent movie!, 24 February 2007

Author: vidopier from France 

I think DH Lawrence would be proud of this film...Pascale Ferran transformed this story we all imagine as an erotic clichÃƒÂ© in a very sensible and sensitive movie. Because Lady Chatterley is not the story of a more or less sex-addict bourgeoise we have seen in so many rubbish erotic movies, inspired by the novel. It is much more about a woman who discovers the materiality of world threw a love story. She discovers also that "some people are not naturally made to command others" and in a way her love story with Parkin is a truly waking up to other people and life around her. She discovers her body and the world of the first industrial revolution has it used to be: unfair and unequal. Lady Chatterlay is not only an erotic story but also a very politic and subversive one. DH Lawrence is well known for being very critical about the British society of 1920&#039;s and the human side-effects of industrial development. Pascal Ferran perfectly understood the deep meaning of the novel. Moreover, she transmuted those ideas in a very french movie (but in fact the best french author cinema). The way she has filmed the two characters is very intimate but never silly, and that&#039;s a great achievement! In a way, her style is very closed to Piala&#039;s one. Harsh and poetic at the same time, precise and evocative, sensible and sensitive. This film is very precious!
